diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, leading to pain, swelling (synovitis), and potential joint destruction over time.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including the joints (arthropathy), skin, kidneys (proteinuria), and heart (pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis characterized by high fevers, rash, arthralgia, and occasionally pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An infection, usually bacterial or viral, that enters a joint and causes inflammation, leading to symptoms like fever and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for several types of arthritis affecting children under 16, involving chronic joint swelling, pain, and stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A multi-system inflammatory disease, often affecting the lungs, skin, and eyes, but can also cause joint problems (arthropathy) and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and mouth, but can also cause joint pain and swelling, skin rashes, and renal issues leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that may present features of lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis, including arthralgia, fever, and occasionally proteinuria and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean Fever
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes recurrent fevers and painful inflammation of your abdomen, lungs, and joints.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis that can affect some people with psoriasis, marked by swollen, painful joints, and may also involve the kidneys (proteinuria) and have associated fever.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome

diagnoses.name: Cardiac arrhythmias
diagnoses.description: Irregular heartbeats that can lead to symptoms like palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there's a deficiency of red cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, can cause nausea and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland is overactive, can cause palpitations, onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to neurological problems, including word-finding difficulty, and anemia symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: An immune-mediated disease that can cause onychodystrophy and sometimes is associated with systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations like angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that disturbs cell growth in your nervous system, causing tumors, often benign, which can manifest as angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Migraines
diagnoses.description: Severe, painful headaches often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light. Cognitive symptoms, including word-finding difficulty, can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Can sometimes lead to cognitive issues like word-finding difficulty.

diagnoses.name: Celiac disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, can present with various non-specific symptoms including nausea.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could explain the oral pain and abnormal electrolytes due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Steven-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes that could cause oral pain, epistaxis, and eye dryness.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, presenting symptoms like oral ulcers (pain), abnormal electrolytes, and potentially laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: While primarily affecting joints, this autoimmune disorder can accompany Sjögren's syndrome, leading to dry eyes, oral pain, and potential epistaxis due to nasal dryness.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that might cause dry eyes, abnormal electrolyte balance, and contribute to mucosal dryness leading to oral pain and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing chronic inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body, associated with oral pain (ulcers), and could potentially explain the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Drug Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause dry eyes, oral discomfort, laryngitis as an allergic response, epistaxis due to mucosal dryness, and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies, particularly of vitamin B12, vitamin C, and vitamin D, could lead to oral pain, dry eyes, and contribute to abnormal electrolytes and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs. Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A complication of bone marrow transplant showing symptoms such as dry eyes, oral pain due to mucositis, and potentially affecting the liver leading to abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Herpes Simplex Virus
diagnoses.description: Primary or reactivation of HSV can lead to oral pain, could potentially affect the eyes (dryness), and cause a systemic reaction influencing electrolyte balance.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various neurologic and psychiatric conditions. Symptoms include fatigue, decreased appetite, and sensory abnormalities, such as tingling and numbness in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia Nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight or shape. Symptoms include hypothermia, decreased appetite, and potential hyperactivity in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood glucose, commonly called blood sugar. Glucose is vital to your health because it's an important source of energy for the cells that make up your muscles and tissues. Complications of diabetes can include sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Heavy Metal Poisoning
diagnoses.description: Exposure to high levels of heavy metals, such as lead or mercury, can cause a variety of symptoms, including hypothermia, dysgeusia (a change in taste sensations), decreased appetite, and sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease, also called chronic kidney failure, involves a gradual loss of kidney function. Your kidneys filter wastes and excess fluids from your blood, which are then excreted in your urine. Advanced chronic kidney disease can cause decreased appetite, dysgeusia, and neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms are unpredictable and vary from person to person but can include sensory neuropathies and, in some cases, hyperactivity.

diagnoses.name: Hypoparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A rare condition in which the body secretes abnormally low levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Low levels of PTH lead to low levels of calcium and high levels of phosphorus in the blood. Symptoms can include hypocalcemia, which can cause sensory neuropathies and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by widespread pain, sleep problems, fatigue, and often emotional and mental distress. People with fibromyalgia may also experience numbness or tingling in the hands and feet, which could be interpreted as sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Autoimmune diseases are conditions involving an abnormal immune response to a normal body part. Depending on the specific disease, symptoms can include dysgeusia, decreased appetite, sensory neuropathies, hyperactivity, among others. Examples include lupus and Sjögren's syndrome.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Zinc affecting taste and skin)
Dehydration (can lead to xerosis and electrolyte imbalances affecting palpitations)
Sjögren's Syndrome (autoimmune disease causing dryness, potentially affecting taste and skin)
COVID-19 (known for symptoms like dysgeusia, palpitations in severe cases)
Drug or Medication Side Effects (certain medications can cause these symptoms as side effects)
Dermatologic Conditions (e.g., eczema or psoriasis leading to skin dryness and potentially hypersensitivity reactions)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Presence of chronic kidney disease as a symptom confirms its diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.rationale: Obstructive sleep apnea is directly mentioned, suggesting its diagnosis among the conditions.

diagnoses.name: Atherosclerosis
diagnoses.rationale: Atherosclerosis is mentioned, indicating it as a primary condition associated with this symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.rationale: Commonly associated with chronic kidney disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and atherosclerosis due to increased cardiovascular strain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Often associated with chronic kidney disease and atherosclerosis due to the impact of high blood sugar on blood vessels and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.rationale: A potential complication of chronic kidney disease, obstructive sleep apnea, atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Hyperlipidemia
diagnoses.rationale: Common in individuals with atherosclerosis and diabetes, and can contribute to the progression of these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Although not directly mentioned, obstructive sleep apnea can exacerbate COPD symptoms and vice versa; a detailed history is needed for diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Frequently observed with chronic kidney disease due to decreased erythropoietin production.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Artery Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Commonly associated with atherosclerosis due to reduced blood flow to the limbs.

diagnoses: PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic Reactions or Food Intolerances (e.g., Lactose Intolerance)
Asthma exacerbation triggered by an infection
Secondary Headaches due to Sinus Disease
Secondary Headaches due to Eye Strain
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral encephalitis, rickettsial diseases)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (as a differential for toxic epidermal necrolysis)
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
Chronic Kidney Disease related to Glomerulonephritis
